The patient has an 11-year history of copious purulent productive cough with extensive negative workup for bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, immunodeficiency, aspiration, malignancy, or active mycobacterial/fungal infection: normal inspiratory/expiratory HRCT, normal bronchoscopy/BAL, normal sweat/CFTR testing, normal immunoglobulins, negative PET-CT and targeted cultures/PCRs. Pulmonary function testing shows proportionate reductions in FEV1 and FVC with a preserved FEV1/FVC and normal lung volumes/DLCO, which does not point to classic obstructive or restrictive disease. Importantly, a 3-month therapeutic trial of low-dose azithromycin (250 mg three times weekly) produced clear clinical benefit: marked reduction in sputum volume and purulence, fewer bronchitic exacerbations, and improved quality of life without adverse effects.

Synthesis/Diagnosis: The most likely diagnosis is chronic suppurative (neutrophilic) bronchitis / chronic productive bronchitis with probable chronic airway bacterial colonization and neutrophilic airway inflammation that is macrolide-responsive. Alternative diagnoses (occult or central bronchiectasis, diffuse panbronchiolitis, or culture‑negative biofilm infections) are now unlikely given negative HRCT, bronchoscopy, and extensive testing, though occult culture‑negative airway colonization remains a plausible mechanism. The macrolide response supports an anti-inflammatory/anti‑biofilm therapeutic effect rather than eradication of an identifiable pathogen.

Why ready: The diagnosis is supported by clinical history (longstanding purulent sputum), exclusion of major alternative causes by comprehensive testing, and a therapeutic response to macrolide therapy that materially improved symptoms and exacerbation frequency. Remaining uncertainties are relatively low and would not substantially change immediate management.

What I would still clarify if additional rounds available: confirm durability of response with longer follow-up off therapy vs maintenance, reassess PFTs for reproducibility and effort, and consider repeat HRCT or targeted airway sampling if symptoms relapse to exclude developing/segmental bronchiectasis or focal structural disease.

Recommended management/next steps: Continue airway clearance physiotherapy and daily techniques; consider ongoing macrolide maintenance (discuss risks/benefits, QT/liver monitoring and antimicrobial stewardship) if sustained benefit—regular ECG and LFT monitoring as previously planned. Optimize prevention: annual influenza and pneumococcal vaccination, smoking avoidance (patient is a non-smoker), prompt treatment of exacerbations with directed antibiotics when indicated, and periodic sputum cultures if sputum character changes. Refer to a specialized airway/bronchiectasis clinic if sputum worsens, imaging becomes abnormal, or macrolide therapy loses effectiveness.

## Clinician's Assessment:
The patient has an 11-year history of copious purulent productive cough with extensive negative workup for bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, immunodeficiency, aspiration, malignancy, or active mycobacterial/fungal infection: normal inspiratory/expiratory HRCT, normal bronchoscopy/BAL, normal sweat/CFTR testing, normal immunoglobulins, negative PET-CT and targeted cultures/PCRs. Pulmonary function testing shows proportionate reductions in FEV1 and FVC with a preserved FEV1/FVC and normal lung volumes/DLCO, which does not point to classic obstructive or restrictive disease. Importantly, a 3-month therapeutic trial of low-dose azithromycin (250 mg three times weekly) produced clear clinical benefit: marked reduction in sputum volume and purulence, fewer bronchitic exacerbations, and improved quality of life without adverse effects.

Synthesis/Diagnosis: The most likely diagnosis is chronic suppurative (neutrophilic) bronchitis / chronic productive bronchitis with probable chronic airway bacterial colonization and neutrophilic airway inflammation that is macrolide-responsive. Alternative diagnoses (occult or central bronchiectasis, diffuse panbronchiolitis, or culture‑negative biofilm infections) are now unlikely given negative HRCT, bronchoscopy, and extensive testing, though occult culture‑negative airway colonization remains a plausible mechanism. The macrolide response supports an anti-inflammatory/anti‑biofilm therapeutic effect rather than eradication of an identifiable pathogen.

Why ready: The diagnosis is supported by clinical history (longstanding purulent sputum), exclusion of major alternative causes by comprehensive testing, and a therapeutic response to macrolide therapy that materially improved symptoms and exacerbation frequency. Remaining uncertainties are relatively low and would not substantially change immediate management.

What I would still clarify if additional rounds available: confirm durability of response with longer follow-up off therapy vs maintenance, reassess PFTs for reproducibility and effort, and consider repeat HRCT or targeted airway sampling if symptoms relapse to exclude developing/segmental bronchiectasis or focal structural disease.

Recommended management/next steps: Continue airway clearance physiotherapy and daily techniques; consider ongoing macrolide maintenance (discuss risks/benefits, QT/liver monitoring and antimicrobial stewardship) if sustained benefit—regular ECG and LFT monitoring as previously planned. Optimize prevention: annual influenza and pneumococcal vaccination, smoking avoidance (patient is a non-smoker), prompt treatment of exacerbations with directed antibiotics when indicated, and periodic sputum cultures if sputum character changes. Refer to a specialized airway/bronchiectasis clinic if sputum worsens, imaging becomes abnormal, or macrolide therapy loses effectiveness.
